answers.answer: Please first just calm down.  In order to have PCOS you should have 2 of the 3 symptoms:  irregular periods, follicles on ovaries by u/s, and hirsutism (increase in body hair).  Many (but not all) people are also overweight.  I was diagnosed because I had 17 follicles on each of my ovaries and a lengthy history of irregular cycles (33-54 days, but even longer when I was in my teens).  PCOS is caused by insulin resistance therefore the treatment for it is simple - metformin.  Sometimes this helps a lot, sometimes not.  PCOS can make conceiving difficult because your periods are unpredictable and you will have fewer periods than a normal person in any given year.  Also if your cycles are long, it is possible that the egg is "geriatric" by the time the sperm come along and this too would make conceiving hard.  The fact that you did have 12 on each ovary does not mean you have PCOS but is something to think about if you have any of the other symptoms.  And remember this is a syndrome(a collection of symptoms) - not a disease.  It is nothing to be scared about.

oh and there is a certain number of follicles they are supposed to see by ultrasound.  I can't remember how many but maybe more than 10-12 of a certain size??  ALso just another note, my OB said follicles are totally normal and no big deal if you have no other symptoms.  It was only when I went to the reproductive endocrinologist and she asked about my other symptoms that they found/thought I have PCOS.  SO if you have normal cycles you are probably fine.
